questions.text: 1. Identify the following method of testing antibiotic sensitivity.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an E-test (epsilometer) which is a diffusion and dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity.

It is a quantitative technique for determining antimicrobial susceptibility and minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC).

* An absorbent strip containing a predefined gradient (serial dilution) of antibiotic concentration immobilized along its length is placed on a lawn inoculum of a bacterium.

* An elliptical zone of inhibition is produced surrounding the strip. 

*

The antibiotic concentration at which the ellipse edge intersects the strip is taken as the MIC value.

The given image shows another E-test.



The antibiotic sensitivity tests are classified as follows:

* Diffusion methods: 

* Kirby–Bauer disk diffusion method

* Stokes disk diffusion method

* Dilution methods: 

* Broth dilution

* Agar dilution

* Diffusion and dilution method:

* E–test (Epsilometer)

* Automated methods:

* VITEK 2 

* Phoenix system 

The disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method. 

To perform Kirby-Bauer’s disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface.

Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive)

The below image shows the Kirby-Bauer disk diffusion method.



The below image shows Tube dilution method.



The below image shows Stokes method

questions.text: 2. A microbiologist conducts a reverse CAMP test and obtains results, as shown below. Which of the following is correct regarding the test?

choices.text: Bacteria A is Clostridium tetani, B is Streptococcus agalactiae
Bacteria A is Staphylococcus aureus, B is Clostridium perfringens
Bacteria A is Staphylococcus aureus, B is Streptococcus agalactiae
Bacteria A is Clostridium perfringens, B is Streptococcus agalactiae

questions.solution:
In the given test,

* Bacteria A is Clostridium perfringens and 

* Bacteria B is Streptococcus agalactiae. 

Reverse CAMP test :

The test is called the reverse CAMP test because the CAMP factor produced by Streptococcus agalactiae is used for the detection of Clostridium perfringens.

C. perfringens is streaked over the center of the plate and Streptococcus agalactiae is streaked at right angles to it. A positive reverse CAMP test shows the presence of an arrow-shaped zone of enhanced hemolysis pointing towards C. perfringens. α-toxin produced by C. perfringens interacts with the CAMP factor and produces synergistic hemolysis.



CAMP test :

The CAMP (Christie, Atkins,Munch-Peterson) test is used to identify group B,  β-streptococci based on their ability to form CAMP factor, which causes synergistic hemolysis with β-hemolysin formed from Staphylococcus aureus.

When Streptococcus agalactiae is inoculated perpendicular to a Staphylococcus aureus grown on blood agar, a characteristic arrow-head zone of hemolysis is seen. The group B streptococci hydrolyze sodium hippurate and give a positive CAMP test.

questions.text: 3. A 72-year-old woman presented with weakness, abdominal pain, and a 10 kg weight loss over the past month. Physical examination revealed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites. She was referred to a tertiary center but passed away a few weeks later. An autopsy of the liver is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of the liver shows multiple nodular metastases, suggestive of metastatic malignancy of the liver.

Metastatic malignancy of the liver is more common than primary hepatic neoplasia. The most common primary sources are the colon, breast, lung, and pancreas. However, primary malignancy from any organ may spread to the liver.

In most cases, multiple nodular metastases may be seen, causing hepatomegaly. The liver weight can exceed several kilograms. In some cases, a solitary metastatic nodule may be present, which can be surgically resected. Massive destruction of hepatocytes or direct obstruction of major bile ducts may cause jaundice.

questions.text: 4. A 63-year-old woman who is a known case of tuberculosis was admitted to the hospital. Physical examination showed diffuse rales on auscultation and hepatosplenomegaly on palpation. Chest x-ray showed bilateral diffuse alveolar opacities and faint reticulonodular infiltrates. The image below shows the lung specimen of this patient. By which route would have TB bacilli spread to give rise to this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image point towards a diagnosis of miliary tuberculosis, and it is spread via hematogenous dissemination. The gross image shows characteristic millet-sized white nodules scattered throughout the lung parenchyma, which is typically seen in miliary tuberculosis.

Chest x-ray appearance of ARDS varies, depending on the severity and typically shows bilateral diffuse alveolar opacities with dependent atelectasis in some cases. The opacities can have a patchy ground-glass appearance. Hematogenous dissemination of the bacteria through arterial and venous systems leads to the manifestations of the disease in various organ systems.

Miliary pulmonary disease occurs when organisms draining through the lymphatics enter the venous blood and circulate back to the lung. It can result from progressive primary disease, reactivation of latent foci, and iatrogenic exposure (lithotripsy, urethral catheterization, cardiac valve homograft placement, and solid organ transplantation).

The risk factors for the development of miliary TB include extremes of age, alcohol use, malignancy, HIV, corticosteroid use, connective tissue disease, renal failure, diabetes, and pregnancy.

The clinicopathological patterns of this condition include acute miliary TB (which may present as multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) and ARDS, as in this patient), late generalized TB, and anergic TB (defined histologically by the absence of granulomata). Individual lesions either microscopic or small <2 mm foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered throughout the lung parenchyma. The lesions may coalesce resulting in large areas of consolidation. Serous pleural effusions, tuberculous emyema or obliterative fibrous pleuritis may occur

Laboratory tests may show pancytopenia due to bone marrow infiltration. Other findings could include anemia, thrombocytopenia/cytosis, hyponatremia, and sterile pyuria.

Chest radiography shows a faint reticulonodular pattern distributed fairly uniformly throughout the lungs. 

Histopathology shows granulomas of tuberculosis characteristically contain epithelioid macrophages, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes with central caseation necrosis.

Other tests include genetic testing and AFB smear/culture. Montaux test is negative in miliary TB.

questions.text: 5. A veterinary surgeon presents with fever, muscle pain, joint pain, fatigue, and weight loss for the past few weeks. On further inquiry, he says that his fever persists for weeks before it resolves, only to be followed by a relapse. You obtain his blood sample and inoculate it on the medium shown below to isolate the suspected organism. Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette along with the given image is the Castaneda biphasic medium is suggestive of brucellosis. It is caused by organisms belonging to the Brucella species.

Brucella are small, non-motile, aerobic, capnophilic coccobacilli. The most important species that are pathologic to humans are B. melitensis, B. suis, and B. abortus.

Brucellosis is a zoonosis. It is transmitted to humans from contact with or consumption of contaminated products from goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, pigs, and other animals.

Once the infection is transmitted, these bacteria resist intracellular digestion and proliferate within the reticuloendothelial system for a long time, and become resistant to simple antimicrobial therapy.

Clinically, patients may present with an acute infection comprised of undulant fever, (remitting and relapsing fever), arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. Central nervous system symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Chronic infection tends to be episodic with non-specific symptoms. 

Laboratory diagnosis of brucellosis includes:

* The polymerase chain reaction is the most sensitive and reliable method of detection. 

* Culture: Castaneda method/ biphasic medium. The solid component is the agar slant, and the liquid is the broth. The medium is inoculated with the specimen and incubated for four days in an upright position. Serial subcultures can be obtained by slanting the broth over the agar periodically to inoculate new colonies. 

* Serological methods for specific antibody detection.

* Tests for animals and animal products include tests such as the milk ring tests and Rose Bengal card tests.

* Milk ring test- A sample of milk is mixed well with hematoxylin-stained brucella antigen and incubated. If the sample contains antibodies to brucella antigens, agglutination occurs with the agglutinate rising to the top as a blue ring. If the sample does not contain antibodies to brucella antigens, the whole of the sample is uniformly stained blue. 

Treatment includes antimicrobial therapy with at least two agents for six weeks duration. The preferred combination is intramuscular streptomycin 0.75-1 g per day for two to three weeks along with doxycycline 100 mg BD for six weeks. 

Prevention of brucellosis is important by screening and abiding by safety standards in farms and dairy industries, and also by pasteurization of milk and milk products.

Pearl PM0001: Organisms and selective Culture Media

Appropriate culture media for various bacteria:

Organism Medium for culture

ludlam’s medium
salt milk agar
Strep. Pyogenes Crystal violet blood agar

Corynebacterium Potassium tellurite agar

Mcleod medium
B.anthrax PLET medium
B.cereus MYPA (Mannitol egg yolk phenol red polymyxin agar)
PEMBA(polymyxin in egg yolk mannitol bromothymol blue agar
Clostridium  CCFA ( cefoxitin cycloserine fructose agar)
Shigella DCA, XLD, SSA
Salmonella Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium
Vibrio TCBS
Monsur GTTA

H. influenza Fildes agar
Levinthal medium

questions.text: 6. You are assessing a sample of water for fecal contamination which had a negative coliform count and performing the test shown below. What is the interpretation of the same?

choices.text: Contamination occured a long time ago
Sample has been cross contaminated by another sample

questions.solution:
The image shows stormy fermentation of lactose in litmus milk. This finding is caused by Clostridium perfingens type A.

The fermentation of lactose by this organism leads to the formation of acid which coagulates the casein in litmus milk. The clotted milk is disrupted due to vigorous gas production and this characteristic finding is obtained that is called stormy fermentation.

The presence of spores of Clostridium perfringens in natural water suggests that fecal contamination has occurred. But in the absence of the coliform group, it suggests that fecal contamination is from a long time ago. They can also be used to assess filtration systems.

Clostridium perfringens also occurs regularly in feces but in much smaller numbers than E. coli. The spores are capable of surviving in water for a long time, and they usually resist chlorination.

questions.text:
7. A 65-year-old man presents with a dull aching pain in the right upper quadrant and pruritus. He also had jaundice, clay-colored stools, dark urine, and weight loss for the past three weeks. Medical records show a history of infection with Clonorchis sinensis. Laboratory investigations and the gross appearance of the liver are given below. Which of the following types of cancer is this patient most likely suffering from?

Lab investigations:

* Elevated CA 19-9

* Immunohistochemistry (IHC)- positive for cytokeratin 7
questions.solution:
The patient has cholestatic symptoms (jaundice, clay-colored stools, and darkened urine) along with a history of infection with Clonorchis. The image shows a large non-encapsulated, well-demarcated, white-tan nodular intrahepatic mass. These features point toward the diagnosis of cholangiocarcinoma, which is an adenocarcinoma.

Cholangiocarcinoma (CCA) is the second most common primary malignant tumor of the liver after HCC. It is a malignancy of the biliary tree, arising from bile ducts within and outside of the liver.

CA 19-9 is a tumor marker and cytokeratin 7 is an IHC marker expressed in cholangiocarcinoma. 

The risk factors include the following:

* Infestation by liver flukes (particularly Opisthorchis and Clonorchis species).

* Chronic inflammatory diseases of the large bile ducts, such as

* primary sclerosing cholangitis

* hepatolithiasis

* fibropolycystic liver disease

* Hepatitis B and C or non-alcoholic fatty liver disease - also have a higher risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) 

* Other less-established, potential risk factors include:

* inflammatory bowel disease

* obesity

* cirrhosis

* diabetes

* alcohol and tobacco. 

Precursor lesions: Biliary intraepithelial neoplasias, mucinous cystic neoplasms, and intraductal papillary biliary neoplasia

Histopathology:

Extrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma generally presents as small lesions and causes obstructive lesions at the time of diagnosis. Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinomas track along with the intrahepatic portal system and create a branching tumor within a portion of the liver.

The tumors are grey, firm nodules within the bile duct wall while some may be diffusely infiltrative lesions. Most tumors are moderate to well-differentiated with clearly defined glandular/tubular structures lined by malignant epithelial cells

They incite marked desmoplasia and appear to be firm due to the desmoplastic reaction. Regardless of the location, these tumors are typical adenocarcinomas that often produce mucin. Lymphovascular and perineural invasion lead to distant metastasis. 

Other options:

Option A- Angiosarcoma is a type of sarcoma which occurs in association with vinyl chloride exposure. The gross features include hemorrhagic necrosis, cystic degeneration, fibrosis, and apparent multicentricity.

Option B- Hepatic lymphoma is a rare disease seen in middle-aged men in association with Hepatitis B and C, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Most cases present as diffuse large cell B-lymphomas. It usually appears as a pale whitish tumour with central calcification. 

Option D- Adenosquamous carcinoma is a type of cholangiocarcinoma that is seen in a very small percentage of patients and is unlikely to be the most likely type.

Pearl PM0276: Pathological Conditions and Associated Neoplasms

MALT: Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue

questions.text: 8. The following image which shows coconut cake rectum is seen in
questions.solution:
Coconut cake rectum is seen in Trichuris trichiura.

T.  trichiura inhabits the cecum and ascending colon. They bury their thin heads into the intestinal lining, causing edema, loosening the elastic epithelium, and weakening the surrounding muscles. This leads to loss of support and rectal prolapse. Other clinical features include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth, and developmental defects.

Heavy infection with Trichuris trichiura may show white bodies of worms hanging from the inflamed mucosa, the so-called coconut cake rectum.

Diagnosis is done by fecal smears showing the barrel-shaped ovum of T. trichiura. Albendazole is the drug of choice (400 mg, orally, for 3 days).

questions.text: 9. The gross appearance of a resected specimen from a patient who presented with testicular swelling is shown below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Histopathology is likely to reveal cells showing 'fried-egg' appearance
Postoperative surveillance using tumour markers is advised

questions.solution:
The above image shows a testicular mass that is homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis. This is suggestive of seminoma. 

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumour and it commonly in patients with a history of cryptorchidism. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP). 

Clinical features of testicular carcinoma:

* Painless testicular lump is the most common presenting feature.

* Epididymo-orchitis.

* Severe pain and acute enlargement of the testis because of haemorrhage into the tumour.

* Intra-abdominal spread may cause abdominal or lumbar pain.

* Lung metastases are usually silent but they can cause chest pain, dyspnoea and haemoptysis in the later stages of the disease.

Sonography is mandatorily done in all suspected cases. Tumour markers which may be elevated in up to 50% of cases, should be investigated prior to orchiectomy. This serves as useful in follow-up after surgery.

An orchidectomy through an inguinal incision is performed as a definitive treatment. Surveillance using CT imaging and tumour markers to look for metastasis or relapse is done. It is radiosensitive and responds to radiotherapy.

A homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis, characterizes the gross appearance of the testis in seminoma.



The histological examination shows sheets of uniform cells with clear or water-appearing cytoplasm with varying amounts of glycogen. There is a large central nucleus, with one or two prominent nucleoli, contributing to the 'fried-egg appearance'. These sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa, containing lymphocytic infiltrate.



Pearl PM2119: Most common testicular tumors

Pre-pubertal age group Yolk sac tumor
15–34 years Germ-cell tumors
Adults Seminomatous and non-seminomatous
Elderly age group Lymphoma
Germ-cell testicular tumor Seminoma
Bilateral testicular tumor Lymphoma


Pearl PM2279: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor


AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

Pearl PM2277: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Seminoma

* Non-seminomatous GCTs

* Embryonal carcinoma

* Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type

* Choriocarcinoma

* Teratoma, post-pubertal type

* Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

* Spermatocytic tumour

* Teratoma, prepubertal type

* Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type

* Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

* Leydig cell tumor

* Sertoli cell tumor

* Granulosa cell tumor

* Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

* Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

questions.text: 10. A 74-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department with hemoptysis and severe chest pain. After a few hours, the patient died due to a massive stroke. Autopsy of the lungs revealed pulmonary infarct, as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is true about the type of infarct?

choices.text: It is seen in tissues with dual circulation.
It occurs in solid organs with end arterial circulation.
As time passes, the infarction becomes progressively paler.

questions.solution:
The autopsy specimen of the lung shows hemorrhagic infarct (red infarct). A red infarct usually occurs in tissues with dual blood supply, such as the lungs. All other options are incorrect.

Pulmonary infarction may occur in patients as a result of pulmonary embolism (PE). The clinical features of PE mimic those of myocardial infarction, and the patient presents with severe chest pain, dyspnea, and shock. Some patients may also present with pleuritic pain, and cough. Emboli that lead to pulmonary infarction additionally cause fever and hemoptysis.

 An infarction is an area of ischemic necrosis caused by occlusion of either arterial supply or venous drainage.

* The infarctions are usually wedge-shaped, with the occluded blood vessel forming the apex and the periphery of the organ, forming the base.

* Fresh infarcts are poorly defined. Over a few days, the margins become better defined due to congestion caused by the inflammatory reaction surrounding the lesion.

* Depending on the appearance, infarction may be either a red infarct or a white infarct. 

Red infarcts occur

* with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion).

* in loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone.

* in tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone.

* in tissues previously congested by a sluggish venous outflow.

* when the flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction).

The infarcts in the lung are almost always hemorrhagic. The extravasated red RBCs in the red infarct are phagocytosed by the macrophages, which convert the heme iron into hemosiderin. Over time, the infarction appears brown in color due to the accumulation of the hemosiderin-laden macrophages. 

The image below shows red infarct in the lung.



White infarcts:

* They occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation (e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney).

* It is seen in organs, where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.

* In contrast to red infarct, the white infarcts tend to become paler as time passes.

The image below shows white infarcts in the spleen.

questions.text:
11. The following specimen is resected from the parotid gland of a 53-year-old female patient. Choose the correct statements about this pathology -

* The tumor has equal incidence in all salivary glands

* There is a female preponderance for this tumor

* Myoepithelial cells are dispersed in a mesenchyme-like background 

* There is a dense lymphoid stroma with germinal centers

* This tumor generates a hot spot on 99mTc pertechnetate scans
questions.solution:
The given gross specimen shows a pale grey surface punctuated by narrow cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous and cystic secretion. This along with the characteristic microscopic appearance, points towards the diagnosis of Warthin's tumor. 

Warthin's tumor is also called papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum. It is a benign neoplasm that is the second most common salivary neoplasm. It has a male preponderance and occurs with a higher incidence in patients who smoke. This tumor occurs almost exclusively in the parotid gland. The tumor generates a characteristic warm or hot spot on Tc-99m-pertechnetate scan. Most tumors are round to oval, encapsulated structures, about 2-5 cm, and easily palpable in the superficial parotid gland

On microscopy, these tumors have cleft-like spaces that are lined by a double layer of neoplastic epithelial cells resting on a dense lymphoid stroma sometimes bearing germinal centers. The upper layer has palisading columnar cells with abundant, finely granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm. The lower cells are cuboidal/polygonal. The presence of mitochondria in the upper layer gives it a granular appearance referred to as oncocytic. Secretory cells are also interspersed. Some foci of squamous metaplasia may be evident.

CT/MRI is used to assess the extent of these tumors and also evaluate lymph node, bony, perineural, and local metastasis. Diagnosis is confirmed by histopathological examination. Bilateral parotid glands should be examined and imaged in the case of Warthin tumors, as these tumors have a tendency for multicentricity and bilaterality. 

Treatment usually involves surgical resection.

Note: Myoepithelial cells dispersed in a mesenchyme-like background are a characteristic feature of pleomorphic adenomas. These tumors are encapsulated and appear as rounded, well-demarcated masses more than 6cm in size. The expansile growth produces protrusions into the surrounding gland, and the cut surface appears grey-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of chondroid. The histopathology of these tumors is shown below.



Pearl PM1674: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

* Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma

* Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

* Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma

* Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

* Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma

* Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland

* Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma

* Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: 12. The appearance of the gross-specimen of the lung shown below, is suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Bronchiectasis is a lung pathology characterized by irregular and irreversible dilatation of bronchi and bronchioles (shown in the lower left part of the gross specimen in the image) due to the permanent destruction of smooth muscle and elastic components in their walls. 

Common predisposing factors include necrotizing pneumonia, bronchial obstruction, autoimmune disorders, and congenital conditions that increase the risk for chronic infections (such as cystic fibrosis and primary ciliary dyskinesia). Obstructive bronchiectasis is caused by numerous conditions such as tumors, foreign body, mucous plugs, and enlarged external lymph nodes. The pathology develops distal to the point of obstruction.

Non-obstructive bronchiectasis is usually the result of chronic lung infections and the accompanying defect in airway clearance.

These patients present with chronic cough and production of copious, foul-smelling purulent sputum.

Mucus plugging and subsequent infection with P. aeruginosa is a common complication of cystic fibrosis. Bronchial obstruction caused by such infections are chronic and result in bronchiectasis despite antibiotics and other treatments.

Other options:

* Empyema is a collection of purulent material in the pleural cavity.

* Atelectasis is due to the collapse of the lung parenchyma. This results in poor oxygenation.

* Pneumothorax is a collection of air in the pleural space.

questions.text: 13. Rukmini underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and the specimen obtained is given below. While going through her history which among the following could be the risk factor for the development of this type of gallstones?
questions.solution:
The above image shows black pigmented gallstones which can occur due to chronic hemolysis, cirrhosis, cystic fibrosis or ileal disease. Presence of mechanical heart valves can lead to chronic hemolysis.

Hyperlipidaemia, obesity, advancing age, female sex (hormones), and contraceptive use are all risk factors for cholesterol stones.

Pigment stones are brown to black. Brown pigmented stones are found in large infected bile ducts, whereas black pigmented stones are found in sterile gall bladder bile.

  • Female
  • Oral contraceptives and pregnancy
  • Obesity and insulin resistance
  • Rapid weight reduction
  • Gallbladder stasis
  • Dyslipidemia syndromes
  
  • Chronic hemolysis 
  • Ileal resection
  • Cystic fibrosis with pancreatic insufficiency

questions.text: 14. The liver specimen from the autopsy of a plastic factory worker is shown in the image below. It shows reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci with blood-filled spaces. Which of the following compounds is most likely to have played a role in the pathogenesis of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of the liver showing multiple reddish-brown hemorrhagic foci and several blood-filled spaces indicates hepatic angiosarcoma, most likely caused by exposure to polyvinyl chloride in the plastic factory.

Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm that has equal gender predilection. The tumor may occur at any site, but most often involves skin, soft tissue, breast, and liver. They are locally invasive and can readily metastasize.  

Hepatic angiosarcomas are associated with exposure to carcinogens. Exposure to polyvinyl chloride, arsenic, and thorotrast can lead to this condition:

* Arsenic - in pesticides

* Thorotrast - a radioactive contrast agent formerly used for radiologic imaging

* Polyvinyl chloride - a widely used plastic

Hepatic tumors and associated agents

Carcinoma

Carcinogens

Hepatocellular adenoma

Oral contraceptives, anabolic steroids

Hepatocellular carcinoma 

Alcohol, thorotrast

Cholangiocarcinoma

Thorotrast

Angiosarcoma

Thorotrast, vinyl chloride, Arsenic


The given histopathological image shows abundant small blood vessels lined by large atypical endothelial cells and atypical mitoses seen in angiosarcoma. The endothelial origin of these tumors can be demonstrated by immunohistochemical staining for CD31 or von Willebrand factor.

questions.text: 15. What is the intermediate host for the organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm). It has no intermediate host.

It is the most common of human helminths and is distributed worldwide. Adult worms live in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum). It is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

The adult worms are large cylindrical worms, with tapering ends, the anterior end being more pointed than the posterior end. Man is the natural host. There is no intermediate host.

Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces containing eggs of Ascaris. The eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva.

Pearl PM0656: Definitive and intermediate hosts of various parasites

Parasite

Definitive host

Intermediate host

Protozoa

 

 

Plasmodium spp.

Female Anopheles mosquito

Man

Babesia

Tick

Pearl PM2374: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form

 Filariform larva Eggs (in fresh stool), larva ( in old stool )

Dracunculus medinensis Third stage filariform larva (L3) Adult worm
Hint: The infective and diagnostic forms are usually the same in the parasites causing autoinfection.

questions.text: 16. A gross specimen of the colon obtained from a 14-year-old boy is shown below. Which of the following statements is false about this pathology?

choices.text: It occurs as a result of a defect in the DNA mismatch repair mechanism.
At least 100 polyps are needed to make the diagnosis.
Prophylactic colectomy is done for patients with APC mutations.
It is associated with congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium.

questions.solution:
The gross specimen in the image shows the presence of multiple polyps in the colon, along with an area suspicious of colorectal carcinoma. Multiple polyps in the colon of a 14-year-old boy make familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) the likely diagnosis.

FAP is an autosomal dominant disorder that is caused by mutations of the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene and not due to defects in the DNA repair mechanism. Defects in DNA mismatch repair genes result in hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, MYH-associated polyposis, and some sporadic colon cancers.

Familial adenomatous polyposis, as the name suggests, is an inherited disorder presenting with numerous colorectal adenomatous polyps. It is an autosomal dominant disease caused by mutations in the APC gene, which is a regulator in the Wnt signaling pathway. At least 100 polyps are required to make a diagnosis of FAP. 

Patients are usually teenagers and multiple polyps are visible in the colon during sigmoidoscopy. It is associated with a variety of extraintestinal manifestations including congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigmental epithelium. Colorectal adenocarcinoma occurs in almost all cases before the age of 50. 

Prophylactic colectomy is recommended in patients with APC gene mutations. The surgeries used are colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA), restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (RPC), or total proctectomy and end ileostomy. The first 2 surgeries are preferred in young patients as it avoids a permanent stoma. 

Note- FAP along with brain tumors is called Turcot syndrome. FAP along with multiple osteomas, skin, and soft tissue tumors is called Gardner syndrome.

Pearl PM1259: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

* Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100

* Gastric and duodenal polyps are present

* Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma

* Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

* Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.

* Epidermoid cysts

* Desmoid tumors in the abdomen

* Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia

* Brain tumors

* Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: 17. The diagnosis based on the gross picture of Gall bladder is
questions.solution:
The gross specimen of the gallbladder is of Cholesterolosis Gallbladder also known as Strawberry gallbladder.

It reveals:

* Brick red GB mucosa with Bright yellow flecks of lipid.

* Multiple cholesterol polyps studding the gallbladder wall.

questions.text:
18. The gross specimen appearance and the histological appearance of a renal specimen from a patient with renal growth are as below. Which of the following statements are true about the underlying condition?

* It arises from the intercalated cells of the proximal tubule

* They are usually well encapsulated

* Most cases are malignant

* Bilateral cases can be seen in patients with tuberous sclerosis

* The histological appearance is due to a large number of mitochondria
questions.solution:
The image shown is of a renal oncocytoma.

Renal oncocytoma arises from the intercalated cells of collecting ducts. Renal oncocytoma is a benign epithelial neoplasm that accounts for approximately 5% to 15% of renal neoplasms. Grossly, these tumors appear tan or mahogany brown, relatively homogeneous, and are usually well encapsulated with a central scar in one-third of cases.

Microscopically, they are composed of large eosinophilic cells having small, round, benign-appearing nuclei that have large nucleoli. Ultrastructurally, these eosinophilic cells have numerous mitochondria. The intensely eosinophilic granular cytoplasm is due to the presence of a large number of mitochondria.

Multiple or bilateral cases are seen associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) and Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome, but most sporadic oncocytomas are usually unilateral and single. 

 

Note:

Oncocytomas are epithelial neoplasms composed of oncocyte epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (due to the accumulation of mitochondria). Oncocytes can arise in various tissues and are referred to as follows: 

* Hurthle cells/Askanazy cells (Thyroid gland).

* Oxyphilic cells (Parotid gland).

* Apocrine metaplasia (Breast).

questions.text: 19. A 60-year-old man was found dead in his apartment. No medical records were found in his place. An autopsy image of his liver is given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the nutmeg appearance of the liver, which is seen in heart failure. Congestive hepatopathy, also known as nutmeg liver or chronic passive congestion of the liver, is liver dysfunction due to venous congestion. It usually occurs due to congestive heart failure.

Pathogenesis:

* It is seen in patients with chronic cardiac lesions, especially those affecting the right heart, which causes the blood to be drained back into the inferior vena cava and then into the hepatic veins.

* Passive congestion of the central veins, triggered by the direct effect of right ventricular pressure on the hepatic veins, leads to enlargement of the liver (congestive hepatomegaly).

Gross appearance:

* In chronic passive hepatic congestion due to heart failure, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown due to congestion and slightly depressed due to cell death and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of the uncongested tan liver.

* The appearance is called a nutmeg liver pattern due to its close resemblance to the cut surface of the nutmeg seed.

Microscopic appearance:

Microscopic examination reveals centrilobular hemorrhage, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, necrosis, and variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout.

questions.text: 20. The below depicted test is used for
questions.solution:
The image shows the string test/ entero test used for diagnosis of giardiasis.

Enterotest (String test) is a useful method for obtaining duodenal specimen.

A coiled thread inside a small weighted gelatin capsule is swallowed by the patient, after attaching the free end of the thread in the cheek. The capsule passes through the stomach to the duodenum. After 2 hours, the thread is withdrawn, placed in saline, and is mechanically shaken. The centrifuged deposit of the saline is examined for Giardia.
